results.name: Kylie Robertson
results.biography:
Kylie Robertson trained as a Scientific Photographer at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology(RMIT) then began lecturing at Darwin University's Department of Fine Arts shortly after graduating, where she specialised in new media and photographic studies. In 1998 she returned to Melbourne where she completed her post-graduate degree in Film and Television at the Victorian College of the Arts, specialising in multimedia. During this time Kylie wrote, produced, and directed 'Silent Passages'which received wide acclaim both nationally and internationally, including a spot at MILIA 2000 in Cannes, France.

Kylie's desire to see convergent media come to life on the computer screen has driven her from a self developed interactive film maker, to multiple working roles within the industry and an Australian Film Commission funded interactive drama pilot - Jupiter Green. She has worked as a lecturer, screen designer, interactive content creator, project manager and post-production artist.

results.name: Andreas Boehmer
results.biography: Andreas Boehmer completed a Bachelor of Arts (multimedia) at Victoria University in 2001 then went on to teach multimedia at Victoria University, as well as working as a freelance multimedia producer on website and CD-Rom productions. In 2003 Andreas studies for a Master of Multimedia at Swinburne University of Technology.

results.name: Edmund Chiu
results.biography:
Edmund Chiu, a Sydney based photographer and new media designer has produced and directed several multimedia productions since graduating from Victorian College of the Arts with Interactive Media in 1999. At VCA he extended the use of interactivity to explore photography, a medium which he was formally trained in. There, he wrote and directed Multiple Xposure, an interactive CD Rom that explores a photographer with multiple personalties through the perception of dance, live action, photographic images and soundscape. The CD Rom has exhibited in shows from Melbourne, America to Japan.

His work primarily deals with human behaviour. In 2000, he continued working with the performing arts industry. As a producer and director, he extracted elements from the CD Rom and transformed Multiple Xposure into a multimedia dance performance titled LUCID. It was performed to a full house at Revolver Upstairs for Melbourne Fringe Festival. LUCID deals with the issues in religious beliefs, homosexuality, violence and psychology. Again he worked with composer Brett Aplin who composed the soundscape to Multiple Xposure. LUCID received rave reviews and was awarded Melbourne Fringe Movement Award for Definition of New Boundaries. LUCID was also performed at St Kilda Film Festival Fusion at The George Ballroom, St Kilda in 2001.

He was commissioned by David Pledger from Not Yet Its Difficult to work on his play titled ¿K¿, a theatrical piece using projected images interacting with the actors about surveillance. It was performed at Melbourne Theatre Company.

Edmund has also worked with Australian Dance Theatre for the annual season of
Ignition in 2001. He collaborated with Lina Limosani (choreographer of Multiple Xposure) with animated visuals to ¿It¿s not for me¿, a piece about violence and religion. It was performed at ADT days before the September 11 incident.

In 2002, Edmund completed his Master of Multimedia at Monash University and is currently working in Sydney as an advertising photographer.

results.name: Walid Ra'ad

roles_in_work.title: The Dead Weight of a Quarrel Hangs
The Dead Weight of a Quarrel Hangs

results.biography: Walid Raad is a media astist and an Assistant Professor of Art at Cooper Union in New York, whose works include textual analysis, video, perofrmance and photography projects. He is also a memeber of the Arab Image Foundation (Beirut/New York) and founding member of the Atlas Group.

results.name: Frank Mosvold
results.biography: Frank Mosvold (born 7 May 1965) is a Norwegian film and television producer. He has a B.S. in economics from Babson College (Wellesley, Ma) and Master in fine art in film production from Loyola Marymount University (Los Angeles, CA). In 1996 Frank Mosvold started his own production company, Kool Produktion AS.  He has produced several award-winning shorts, including the Terje Vigen award at the Norwegian Short Film Festival for the film An Accidental Story. In 2004 he begin work on the animated television series together with Tom Petter Hansen and Trond Morten Venaasen. Together they have produced the animated television series Hubert and Sunshine Kathy (also known as Ella Bella Bingo) and its 2020 film adaptation.
